explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is 54degC (c.c.) (ICSC, 1999), which is classified into Category 3, those containing stabilizers are classified into Class 3 and Class 8 (UN#2218) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though containing unsaturated bonds. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Class 3 and Class 8 (UN#2218) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures; the auto-ignition temperature is 360degC (ICSC, 1999)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Class 3 and Class 8 (UN#2218) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 900 mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 193mg/kg (EHC 191(1997)), 360mg/kg (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), 1,250mg/kg (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), 1,350mg/kg (EHC 191(1997)), 2,500mg/kg (EHC 191(1997)), 2,520mg/kg (EHC 191(1997)7), and 2,590mg/kg (ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 430mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rabbit LD50 (dermal route) of 295mg/kg, 640mg/kg, 750mg/kg and 950mg/kg (EHC 191 (1997)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the LC50 value (4 hours) of 3.6 with >5.100 mg/L (EHC 191 (1997)), calculated from testing data of rat (inhalation of vapor), with the smaller fixed value adopted. An LC50 value (4 hours) of 3.6 mg/L is converted into 1,200 ppm, using a conversion factor of 1 mg/L = 339 ppm. Based on the rat LC50 value (4 hours) was lower than 90% of the saturated vapor concentration (5,220 ppm) under a saturated vapor pressure of 529 Pa (25degC), Acrylic acid, under the test conditions, was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on the LC50 value (4 hours) calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of mist) of 11.1 mg/L (1 hour) and 7.5 mg/L (2 hours) (EHC 191 (1997)). Of LC50 values of 2.8 and 3.8 mg/L (4 hours) calculated, the lower value was adopted for classification purposes.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (EHC 191 (1997) and EU-RAR No.28 (2002)): 1-3-minitue application of the undiluted solution to the skin suggests corrosion.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on eye irritation tests (EHC 191 (1997) and EU-RAR No.28 (2002)): cicatrices in the eyelids and corneal opacity are still evident after 20 days of the application, both of which are considered irreversible effects.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitizer: Classification not possible Skin sensitizer: Not classified
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: No data available Skin sensitizer: Based on the description in EHC 191 (1997) and EU-RAR No.28 (2002) - acrylic acid may or may not cause skin sensitization in guinea pigs. Impurities and polymerization inhibitors contained in acrylic acid cause skin sensitization, while purified acrylic acid does not, according to some reports. There is another report on industrial products containing acrylic acid that they have caused skin sensitization in more than 450 workers since 1989. Acrylic acid per se does not seem to cause skin sensitization.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests) and somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosomae aberration tests) and the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, described in EU-RAR No.28 (2002).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A4 by ACGIH (2001) and Group 3 by IARC (1999). This classification is in consistent with the evaluation of EU (2002): Acrylic acid is not suspected to be a carcinogenic agent (Based on these data, carcinogenic effects are not anticipated to occur.)

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based on the report that no reproductive or developmental toxicity was observed at dosing levels not toxic to parent animals, described in EU-RAR No.28 (2002).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the animal studies including "degeneration and necrosis of liver tissue (oral route); severe irritation of respiratory organs, pulmonary inflammation (inhalation route); pulmonary edema (dermal route)" (EU-RAR No.28 (2002)). The effects on the liver and on the respiratory organs were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2 and Category 1, respectively.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "inflammation of the upper respiratory tract" (CERI Hazard Data 96-27 (1997)), "degeneration of the olfactory epithelia" (MOE Risk Assessment Vol. 3 (2004)). The effects were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 72 hours ErC50=0.13mg/L of the algae (Scenedesmus) (EHC191 (1997) and others.).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 67.8% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=0.35 (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), it was claasified into Not classified.
